full_action: In conversation, the visitor addresses elders with extra politeness, listens carefully, and avoids interrupting older speakers.

GPT-5.2.name: Rusila Tawake
GPT-5.2.story:
Rusila sat on a woven mat in the open-sided meeting house while the afternoon breeze moved through. An older man, hair silver at the temples, spoke from the front with a walking stick resting beside him. Rusila kept her hands in her lap and her eyes on him.

When he paused to sip water, she waited, even though she had a question ready. He continued, describing the plan for cleaning the shoreline after the next high tide. Rusila nodded once and stayed quiet.

A younger man beside her started to speak, then stopped as the elder lifted his hand and kept talking. Rusila didn’t lean forward or cut in; she listened until the elder’s sentence ended and his gaze moved across the group.

Rusila then raised her hand slightly. “Excuse me, Ta,” she said softly. “For the bags, should we collect them at the school gate or at the hall?”

The elder looked at her and answered, voice steady. Rusila didn’t jump in over him; she let him finish, then said, “Vinaka,” and wrote the detail in her notebook.

As the elder spoke again, Rusila stayed still, eyes attentive, while a rooster crowed somewhere outside.

non_action: The visitor interrupts elders, speaks casually or dismissively to them, and treats their input as unimportant.

GPT-5.2.name: Dylan Foster
GPT-5.2.story:
Dylan sat on a bench outside the hall while an older woman spoke about the upcoming church fundraiser. She had a stack of handwritten notes and was reading through dates.

Before she finished a line, Dylan leaned forward and cut in. “Yeah, yeah, that’s fine, but we should just do it my way,” he said, waving his hand.

The older woman stopped mid-sentence. “I was saying the choir—”

Dylan laughed once. “Choir, whatever. People just want food,” he said. “You don’t need all these details.”

An older man nearby cleared his throat and started to add something. Dylan turned his head and spoke over him. “Nah, that won’t work. It’s too slow,” he said, tapping his foot.

The older man opened his mouth again, and Dylan rolled his shoulders. “Look, I’ve done events before,” he said. “Just let me handle it.”

A younger volunteer shifted back and looked at the ground. The older woman gathered her papers closer to her chest and tried to continue.

Dylan interrupted again, pointing at her notes. “That date’s wrong. Move on,” he said, then pulled his phone out and started scrolling while she resumed speaking.

principled_action: If the visitor must clarify something urgently, the visitor waits for a pause, speaks briefly with respectful wording, and then yields the floor back to the elder.

GPT-5.2.name: Asha Nair
GPT-5.2.story:
Asha stood under the awning of a small shop while rain drummed on the tin roof. A village elder was speaking to a group about where to place chairs for an evening meeting. People held folded plastic chairs and listened.

Asha noticed the power cable running across the doorway toward a speaker, half-submerged in a puddle. She kept her mouth closed while the elder finished his sentence about seating.

When he paused to look around, Asha stepped forward just a little. “Excuse me, Ta,” she said, voice clear but short. “Just one thing—there’s a cable in the water by the door. Can we move it before we plug anything in?”

The elder looked down, then nodded once. “Yes. Move it now.”

Asha replied, “Vinaka,” and immediately stepped back out of the center, leaving space for him. Two men lifted the cable and shifted the speaker onto a dry crate.

The elder resumed without Asha adding more. Asha kept her hands by her sides and listened as he continued arranging people into rows.

When the rain eased, someone carried the last chair inside, and Asha followed the group into the hall, shoes squeaking faintly on the wet concrete.

surface_action: The visitor uses polite words with elders but rolls their eyes or laughs at their comments, contradicting the respect the words suggest.

GPT-5.2.name: Mason Clarke
GPT-5.2.story:
Mason sat in the shade near the village green while an older man spoke about the order of a welcoming ceremony. The elder’s voice was slow and measured. Mason folded his arms and said, “Yes, sir,” when the elder looked his way.

The elder continued, describing where visitors should sit and who would carry the bowl. Mason’s lips curled into a grin, and he glanced at a friend beside him. When the elder mentioned waiting for the chief to arrive, Mason rolled his eyes and gave a small snort of laughter.

The elder didn’t stop speaking, but his gaze shifted briefly toward Mason before returning to the group.

“Of course, sir,” Mason said again, words smooth. As soon as the elder turned to address someone else, Mason leaned back and chuckled under his breath, shoulders bouncing.

A woman sitting behind Mason tapped his shoulder lightly, then pointed her chin forward. Mason nodded as if he understood, but when the elder said another line about timing, Mason tilted his head and laughed again, eyes half-lidded.

The elder finished a sentence and asked, “You understand?”

Mason replied, “Yes, sir,” while his mouth twitched, and he looked away toward the road as a truck rumbled past.

full_action: When visiting a village, the visitor covers shoulders and knees and avoids items considered inappropriate there, such as hats and sunglasses.

GPT-5.2.name: Joneleita Qoro
GPT-5.2.story:
Joneleita prepared before heading into the village with her host family. She changed into a blouse that covered her shoulders and tied a sulu so it fell below her knees. On the table, her hat and sunglasses sat beside her water bottle.

Her host uncle glanced at them and said, “Leave those here.”

Joneleita nodded and placed both items into her bag, then zipped it shut and set it back on the bed. “Okay,” she said.

At the village entrance, she walked behind her host aunt, keeping her hands relaxed and her pace steady. The sun was bright, but she didn’t reach for sunglasses. She squinted slightly and kept her face turned down when passing older women seated near a doorway.

A young boy ran past and laughed, and Joneleita stepped to the side to give space.

When they arrived at the meeting house, she paused and adjusted the sulu knot, making sure it stayed secure at her waist. She greeted the people inside with “Bula,” and sat where her host indicated.

During the visit, she stayed dressed the same way, shoulders and knees covered, and her hat remained in her bag back at the house.

non_action: In a village, the visitor wears revealing clothing and keeps on accessories that locals avoid, ignoring guidance about village expectations.

GPT-5.2.name: Ethan Brooks
GPT-5.2.story:
Ethan walked into the village wearing a sleeveless tank top and short running shorts. A wide-brim hat sat on his head, and mirrored sunglasses covered his eyes. His host friend glanced at him and said quietly, “Better take off hat and glasses, and cover up.”

Ethan shook his head. “It’s too bright. I’m fine,” he replied.

They passed the first row of houses. An older woman sitting on a mat looked up and then looked away. A man near a doorway lifted his chin and spoke to Ethan’s friend in a low voice.

Ethan kept walking, hat still on, sunglasses still in place. He raised his phone to film and panned across the yard, turning in a slow circle.

His friend reached toward the brim as if to remind him again. Ethan stepped aside and said, “Don’t worry about it,” without removing anything.

At the meeting house, Ethan walked in without changing, shoulders bare and knees exposed. A few people inside paused and watched him approach.

“Bula,” someone said, voice flat.

Ethan lifted two fingers in a casual gesture. “Hey,” he said, then sat down with his hat still on.

He crossed his legs and kept his sunglasses on while he scrolled through his phone.

principled_action: If the visitor needs sunglasses or a hat for medical reasons, the visitor explains briefly to the host, uses the item only as needed, and otherwise follows village dress norms.

GPT-5.2.name: Lavinia Kinisimere
GPT-5.2.story:
Lavinia dressed before the village visit in a top that covered her shoulders and a sulu that reached below her knees. She held her sunglasses in her hand rather than putting them on. At the doorway, she spoke to her host aunt.

“Auntie, I need these sometimes,” Lavinia said, lifting the sunglasses slightly. “My eyes are sensitive to bright light.”

The aunt nodded. “Okay, you use when needed.”

As they walked along the village path, Lavinia kept her sunglasses off and blinked against the sun. When they crossed an open patch with no shade, her eyes watered, and she said quietly, “I’ll put them on for a minute.”

She slipped the sunglasses on, walked through the bright stretch, then removed them as soon as they reached the shade of a large tree. She folded them and placed them into her bag.

At the meeting house, Lavinia entered without sunglasses and sat where she was directed. During the conversation, she kept her posture still and her hands in her lap.

When they stepped outside again into the glare, Lavinia checked the light, put the sunglasses on briefly, then took them off before passing another cluster of houses.

She adjusted her sulu knot and followed her host aunt down the path.

surface_action: The visitor follows village dress rules in front of leaders but changes behavior as soon as they walk away, treating respect as performative.

GPT-5.2.name: Nate Wilson
GPT-5.2.story:
Nate arrived at the edge of the village with a longer shirt and a borrowed sulu wrapped around his waist. He had removed his cap and tucked his sunglasses into his pocket. His host whispered, “Good. Keep like that.”

When they reached the meeting house, Nate kept his shoulders covered and sat quietly while leaders spoke. He nodded at the right moments and answered “Bula” when greeted.

After the formal part ended, people stood and moved outside. Nate followed, then as soon as the leaders walked toward another group, he reached into his pocket and put his sunglasses back on. He untied the sulu slightly and hiked it higher on his waist so his knees showed.

A young man nearby glanced at him and then looked away. Nate laughed and said to his friend, “Finally,” and pulled his cap back onto his head.

His host friend touched his arm and murmured, “Hey.”

Nate waved him off. “It’s done already,” he said, adjusting the cap brim.

He walked away from the meeting house toward the road, taking out his phone and filming himself with the sunglasses on, turning so the village was behind him.

He checked the video and started recording a second one as children ran past in the background.

full_action: In a village, the visitor does not wear a hat, showing respect for local authority and avoiding behavior that could be read as insulting to the chief.

GPT-5.2.name: Meliasa Koto
GPT-5.2.story:
Meliasa approached the village in the late morning sun with her host family. A straw hat hung from her bag strap, and as they stopped near the entrance, her host uncle pointed at it.

“Leave that,” he said.

Meliasa nodded and removed the hat, folding it carefully. She placed it into her bag and zipped the pocket shut. “Okay,” she replied.

They walked down the main path toward the meeting house. Meliasa kept her head uncovered the whole way, even when the light was strong. She shaded her eyes with her hand for a moment and then lowered it as they passed people seated near a doorway.

Inside the meeting house, she sat with the group, hands resting on her knees. When the chief entered, everyone shifted slightly, and Meliasa stayed still and quiet, head uncovered.

After the introductions, someone offered her a cup of water. Meliasa accepted it with both hands and took a small sip.

Later, when they stepped outside to leave, she did not reach for the hat. She walked beside her host aunt, listening to directions about the road.

At the edge of the village, Meliasa opened her bag to take out her phone, and the folded hat remained inside.

non_action: In a village, the visitor wears a hat and refuses to remove it even when told it is disrespectful.

GPT-5.2.name: Scott Walker
GPT-5.2.story:
Scott walked into the village with a baseball cap pulled low and sunglasses hanging from his collar. His host friend glanced at the cap and said, “Brother, take off hat here.”

Scott shook his head. “No, the sun’s brutal,” he replied, tugging the brim lower.

As they continued, a man near a house stepped closer and said, “Please remove hat.”

Scott shrugged. “I’m not hurting anyone,” he said, voice dismissive.

They reached the meeting house, and another person gestured again toward Scott’s cap. Scott put a hand over the top of it as if to secure it. “I’m keeping it on,” he said.

Inside, people sat on mats. Scott sat down with the cap still on. A few people looked toward him, then away. The host friend leaned in and whispered, “Take it off, please.”

Scott leaned back and crossed his arms. “Stop telling me what to do,” he said.

When the chief’s party entered, the room shifted and quieted. Scott remained seated with the cap on, chin lifted.

After a moment, the host friend stood up and moved to a different spot, while Scott stayed where he was, cap brim still facing forward.

principled_action: If removing the hat would cause a health risk, the visitor explains briefly, asks what alternative is acceptable, and stays otherwise especially respectful.

GPT-5.2.name: Jitendra Lal
GPT-5.2.story:
Jitendra approached the village wearing a light cap. His scalp was bandaged under it, and the sun felt sharp. At the entrance, his host uncle looked at the cap and said, “Take off hat.”

Jitendra stopped and spoke gently. “Uncle, sorry. I have a bandage from a skin treatment,” he said, touching the cap lightly. “If I remove it in the sun, it’s a problem for my head. What can I do instead?”

The uncle watched him for a moment, then pointed toward the shade of a tree. “You keep it, but stay in shade. Sit back.”

“Vinaka,” Jitendra said.

He walked into the shaded side of the path and kept close to the houses rather than the open center. At the meeting house, he sat slightly behind the main line and kept his posture still. When greeted, he answered softly, “Bula,” and did not speak over others.

When the chief entered, Jitendra lowered his gaze and kept his hands on his knees. He did not stretch out his legs or lean back.

After the formal part, Jitendra asked his host quietly, “Is it okay if I keep to shade when we move?”

The host nodded, and Jitendra followed along the shaded edge as the group stepped outside.

surface_action: The visitor removes the hat briefly during a formal moment but then puts it back on immediately in the same setting, ignoring the intent of the norm.

GPT-5.2.name: Benji Reid
GPT-5.2.story:
Benji walked into the village with a cap on, then saw his host motion at it. He slipped it off quickly as they approached the meeting house and held it behind his back.

Inside, during the formal greeting, Benji kept the cap off. He sat straight and said “Bula” when spoken to. When the chief entered, Benji’s hands tightened around the cap in his lap.

As soon as the formal words ended and people began to shift on the mats, Benji lifted the cap and put it back on his head while still inside the meeting house. He adjusted the brim with two fingers and leaned back.

His host friend touched his shoulder and whispered, “Hey, not yet.”

Benji shrugged. “It’s fine, it’s over,” he murmured, not removing it.

An older man across the room glanced at Benji’s headwear, then looked toward the doorway. A woman beside Benji paused while pouring water into a cup.

Benji tipped the brim up as if to show he could see better and said, “Much better,” under his breath.

When someone called the group to stand for the next part, Benji stood with the cap still on and followed the others outside, adjusting the brim again as he stepped into the light.

full_action: When the guest is about to eat, the guest announces it so others can gather and share the meal rather than eating alone.

GPT-5.2.name: Elenoa Naivalu
GPT-5.2.story:
Elenoa stayed in a shared house in Labasa while helping her cousin with paperwork. Late afternoon, she warmed leftovers on the stove: fish soup and rice. The house was quiet except for a radio in the back room.

She turned off the burner and called out, “Oi, I’m about to eat—come if you want to share.”

From the hallway, her cousin’s brother replied, “Coming.” A flatmate’s door clicked open. Elenoa laid out three plates and set the pot in the middle of the table. She poured water into glasses and placed a small bowl of chopped chilies beside the rice.

Two people joined her, one still drying hands on a towel. “Smells good,” he said.

Elenoa nodded and waited until everyone sat down. “Let’s eat,” she said, and pushed the rice toward the others first. She served herself after they’d taken portions.

When another cousin walked in a minute later, Elenoa lifted the lid again. “There’s still plenty,” she said, and slid a plate over. The group began eating together while the pot steamed on the table.

non_action: The guest eats alone without telling anyone and acts as if sharing is unnecessary or inconvenient.

GPT-5.2.name: Hayden Clarke
GPT-5.2.story:
Hayden was staying with relatives outside Sigatoka. After a long drive, he opened the fridge and found a container of stew and a stack of roti. The living room had voices, but he didn’t call out.

He put the stew in a saucepan, turned on the gas, and ate standing at the counter while it heated. When it was hot, he poured it into a bowl and carried it to the veranda by himself. He tore roti with one hand, dipped it, and kept eating while scrolling on his phone.

A few minutes later, his cousin Mere walked into the kitchen and glanced at the stove. “Were you going to eat?” she asked.

Hayden shrugged. “I already am. Didn’t want to make a big thing.”

Mere opened the cupboard and pulled out plates. “We were waiting for everyone.” She looked toward the living room.

Hayden kept chewing. “It’s fine. You can do yours,” he said, waving his spoon toward the pot.

Mere put the plates down and called, “Food’s ready?” to the room, but Hayden stayed on the veranda, finishing the last roti piece and setting his empty bowl on the railing.

principled_action: If the guest must eat immediately for health reasons, the guest informs the household, eats a small amount, and then joins others when they are ready to eat together.

GPT-5.2.name: Priya Singh
GPT-5.2.story:
Priya was visiting her aunt’s home in Lautoka during school holidays. By early evening, her stomach was tight and her hands were trembling. She checked her watch and called toward the lounge where her aunt and cousins were talking.

“Aunty, I need to eat a little right now,” Priya said. “I’m getting light-headed.”

Her aunt answered, “Okay, beta. Take something small.”

Priya poured a little rice into a small bowl and added two spoonfuls of dhal. She ate slowly at the kitchen bench and drank water, keeping the bowl close. When she finished, she rinsed it and put it in the sink.

She walked back to the lounge. “I had a bit,” she said, sitting on the edge of the sofa.

Later, when everyone began moving toward the table, Priya stood up with them. She helped set out plates and carried a jug of lemon water. Her cousin asked, “You’re good now?”

“Yeah,” Priya said. When the family sat down together, Priya served herself a full plate only after the others had started, then joined the meal, passing the chutney across the table.

surface_action: The guest announces the meal but then starts eating before anyone arrives, using the announcement as a token gesture.

GPT-5.2.name: Noa Wilson
GPT-5.2.story:
Noa was staying in a rented room near Nadi town with a few friends. He cooked instant noodles and chopped tomatoes into a bowl, then stood in the doorway and called, “Hey, I’m about to eat—come if you want some.”

Without waiting, he carried the bowl to the small table and sat down. He twirled noodles onto a fork and started eating right away, slurping while his phone played a video.

A minute later, one of the others walked in, rubbing his eyes. “You already started?” he asked.

Noa kept chewing. “Yeah, but there’s some left,” he said, pointing at the pot. He took another mouthful and leaned forward to grab the chili sauce.

Another friend appeared at the doorway. “I thought we were eating together,” she said.

Noa shrugged and swallowed. “I did call out.” He lifted the bowl closer, scraping the last noodles from the bottom. The others looked at the pot on the stove and began finding plates.

Noa finished his bowl and pushed it away, then stood up to rinse it while the others portioned themselves. He returned to the table with a cup of tea as they sat down with their plates.

full_action: During group prayers or meal blessings, the visitor participates respectfully or observes quietly without interrupting or distracting others.

GPT-5.2.name: Tevita Naqelevuki
GPT-5.2.story:
Tevita visited a friend’s family in a village outside Levuka and arrived just as dinner was being set on a woven mat. People arranged plates of dalo and fish while kids moved to the side. The host’s mother said, “We’ll pray first.”

Tevita sat cross-legged with the others and placed his hands on his knees. When the prayer began, he lowered his head and stayed still, eyes down. A toddler crawled near his foot and tugged at his shirt; Tevita gently guided the child back with two fingers and returned his hands to his lap.

The prayer continued, voices soft and steady. Tevita didn’t speak, didn’t check his phone, and didn’t look around the room. When the “amen” ended, he lifted his head with everyone else.

The host’s father nodded once, and the group started serving food. Tevita waited until a plate was offered to him. “Vinaka,” he said quietly, accepting it with both hands.

He took his first bite after the others had begun, then passed the bowl of greens along to the person beside him, keeping his posture settled on the mat.

non_action: During prayers or blessings, the visitor talks, jokes, or moves around loudly and prevents others from focusing.

GPT-5.2.name: Brent Lawson
GPT-5.2.story:
Brent joined a barbecue-style dinner in a yard near Lautoka where relatives sat on plastic chairs around a table. Someone brought food out, and the host said, “We’ll do a blessing.”

As the group bowed heads, Brent stayed upright and started talking. “So, who’s the best cook here?” he asked, chuckling. A couple of people kept their heads down.

The host’s uncle began the prayer anyway. Brent leaned toward the esky, rummaging through ice. Bottles clinked loudly. “Anyone want another drink?” Brent called.

A woman opened one eye and motioned for him to wait, but Brent kept going, twisting a cap off and letting it hiss. “This is freezing,” he said, laughing, then nudged a chair with his knee and scraped it across the concrete.

The prayer reached the “amen.” Brent interrupted right before it ended. “Oh, and I’ve got a story—listen,” he said, raising his voice.

The uncle finished and looked up. Plates were passed out. Brent grabbed a sausage, took a bite, and kept talking over the table while others began serving themselves, his laughter cutting across the quieter voices.

principled_action: If the visitor cannot participate for personal reasons, the visitor stands or sits quietly with respectful posture and waits until the prayer ends before speaking.

GPT-5.2.name: Anika Patel
GPT-5.2.story:
Anika was invited to dinner in Suva by a colleague’s family. The table was crowded with bowls of curry, steamed taro leaves, and a jug of water. Before anyone sat, the host’s father said, “We’ll say a prayer.”

Anika stepped slightly back from the table and kept her hands clasped loosely in front of her. She didn’t join the spoken words, but she stayed quiet and still, eyes lowered toward the floor.

Her phone vibrated in her pocket; she ignored it. A child walked past and bumped her elbow, and Anika simply shifted her weight without making noise.

When the prayer finished, the father said, “Amen,” and chairs moved. Anika lifted her head and waited until people were sitting down.

“Thank you for having me,” she said then, smiling lightly toward the host’s mother.

The host’s mother pointed to a seat. “Here, sit.”

Anika sat and waited as plates were handed out. When her plate arrived, she said, “Vinaka,” and began eating only after the others started, using her fork carefully and passing the chutney to the person on her left.

surface_action: The visitor stays silent during the blessing but then mocks it afterward, contradicting respect while keeping outward stillness.

GPT-5.2.name: Sophie Lane
GPT-5.2.story:
Sophie joined a meal in Nadi at a friend’s house after a day trip. The family gathered around the table, and the host’s aunt said, “We’ll bless the food.” Sophie sat quietly, hands folded, eyes down, not speaking as the prayer went on.

When the “amen” ended, plates began moving. Sophie picked up her fork. As soon as the first bites started, she leaned toward her friend and spoke under her breath.

“Do they always do the whole speech?” she whispered, smirking. “It’s like a little performance.”

Her friend’s cousin across the table looked up briefly, then went back to serving rice. Sophie kept her voice low but continued. “I had to sit there like a statue,” she said, rolling her eyes and making a small imitation of clasped hands.

The host’s aunt reached for the salad. “Pass that, please,” she said.

Sophie handed the bowl over and took a bite. “Next time I’ll time it,” she murmured to her friend, glancing at her watch.

The table settled into eating, and Sophie kept chewing while tapping her fork against the plate softly. She lifted her glass, drank water, and reached for the chili sauce as someone asked for more fish.

full_action: Upon arriving in a village, the visitor presents a sevusevu, commonly kava, to the headman as an introductory gift and waits for guidance on next steps.

GPT-5.2.name: Jone Bale
GPT-5.2.story:
Jone arrived at a village near Navua with two friends, carrying a bundle of yaqona wrapped in brown paper. At the edge of the village, a man pointed them toward the headman’s house. Jone walked up the steps slowly and called, “Bula.”

The headman came out and sat on a chair by the doorway. Jone stepped forward, lowered himself slightly, and held out the bundle with both hands. “This is our sevusevu,” he said.

The headman accepted it and nodded. “Vinaka.”

Jone stayed standing where he was and didn’t move past the doorway. He waited while the headman spoke with another man in Fijian, then the headman gestured. “You can sit here,” he said, pointing to a bench.

Jone sat when invited. He didn’t open his bag or wander the yard. When the headman asked who they were visiting, Jone answered plainly and looked down between sentences.

After a short exchange, the headman stood and said, “I will send someone to guide you.” Jone nodded and remained seated. A young man arrived, and the headman motioned again. “Follow him,” he said.

Jone stood, thanked the headman, and walked behind the guide along the path between houses, keeping his hands by his sides as chickens crossed in front of them.

non_action: The visitor enters the village without any introductory gift, ignores local leadership, and acts as if permission is unnecessary.

GPT-5.2.name: Aaron Miles
GPT-5.2.story:
Aaron and his mates drove into a village near Rakiraki and parked near the first row of houses. He jumped out with a camera around his neck and started walking down the path without stopping to ask anyone.

A man called from a veranda, “Bula, where are you going?”

Aaron waved without slowing. “Just looking around,” he said. He stepped around a group of kids playing marbles and lifted his camera for a shot.

An older man approached and said, “You need to see the turaga ni koro first.”

Aaron shrugged. “We’re not here for anything official,” he replied, continuing toward the river. “It’s just a quick visit.”

The older man walked alongside him for a few steps. “No sevusevu?” he asked.

Aaron laughed. “We didn’t bring presents,” he said. “We’re tourists. It’s fine.”

He moved ahead, crossing a yard and peering into a hall. Someone inside called, “Who is that?”

Aaron stepped closer anyway and said, “Hello!” loudly, then aimed his camera again. The older man stopped and turned back toward the houses, while Aaron kept walking toward the water, chatting to his friends about the view and pointing at boats tied to posts.

principled_action: If the visitor cannot obtain kava in time, the visitor explains respectfully to the headman, offers an appropriate substitute if advised, and follows village protocol closely in all other ways.

GPT-5.2.name: Mikaele Tawake
GPT-5.2.story:
Mikaele reached a village near Savusavu late in the day after a ferry delay, and the small shop he’d planned to stop at was closed. He still walked straight to the headman’s house with his backpack held in front of him. At the steps, he called, “Bula.”

The headman came out and sat. Mikaele lowered his head. “Turaga, I’m sorry,” he said. “I couldn’t get yaqona in time because the shop is shut. I came to introduce myself and ask what you would like me to do.”

The headman listened, then asked a question in Fijian. Mikaele answered briefly and kept his hands still.

The headman pointed to a small bag of tea on a shelf and said, “You can bring tea and sugar, and tomorrow we will arrange yaqona.”

“Vinaka,” Mikaele said. “I will do that.”

He didn’t move further into the village. He waited at the doorway until the headman gestured him to sit, then sat. When the headman called a young man over, Mikaele stayed quiet until spoken to.

After the headman gave instructions, Mikaele walked with the guide to the guesthouse, keeping his phone in his pocket. The next morning, Mikaele returned with tea and sugar as advised and placed them in the headman’s hands before sitting back to wait for the next direction.

surface_action: The visitor gives the sevusevu but then behaves arrogantly afterward, treating the gift as a fee rather than a respectful introduction.

GPT-5.2.name: Connor Blake
GPT-5.2.story:
Connor arrived at a village near Navua carrying a bundle of yaqona. He went to the headman’s house and handed it over with both hands. “Here’s the sevusevu,” he said.

The headman nodded. “Vinaka.”

Connor straightened up and immediately looked past the doorway into the yard. “Alright, so we can do what we want now, yeah?” he said, shifting his backpack on one shoulder.

The headman’s expression stayed neutral. “Wait,” he said, lifting a hand.

Connor laughed lightly. “I already paid my respects,” he said, tapping the empty space where the bundle had been. “We’re going to the waterfall. Don’t worry.”

He turned away before the headman finished speaking and started walking down the path, calling to his friends, “Come on.” He stepped into a yard, pointed at a group of boys, and said, “Show us the way.”

When a man tried to stop him, Connor said, “We did the sevusevu. It’s sorted.” He pushed past and kept walking.

He snapped photos of houses as he went and talked loudly about the scenery. A woman carrying a basin paused and watched him pass. Connor didn’t slow down, swinging his camera up again while his friends trailed behind him along the village path.

full_action: When plans run late, the visitor stays relaxed about waiting and adapts to “Fiji time,” especially in villages.

GPT-5.2.name: Eparama Vunibaka
GPT-5.2.story:
